codes.label: Empirical
codes.evidence: The analysis is based on the Swiss Electoral Study 2007, which was carried out straight after the 2007 parliamentary elections. In addition to a citizen survey, candidates were studied. Although the design of the two surveys is different, they both contain a set of 13 identical questions.

codes.label: National
codes.evidence: focusing on the representation of income groups in Switzerland. More precisely, it focuses on the congruence between policy preferences of income groups and the preferences of their representatives in parliament. This view of representation, in line with a 'selection model' of political representation (see Mansbridge, 2009), puts emphasis on the importance of having representatives who share similar preferences, in terms of broad policy options and values, with their electorate. The overarching research question addressed in this paper is as follows: Are the policy preferences of less affluent citizens less well represented in the Swiss National Council1 (lower house of the Federal Assembly)

codes.label: Partially
codes.evidence: The study focuses primarily on policy congruence/representation rather than attitudes toward parliament itself. However, attitudes about government intervention and economic policy are examined as they relate to representation: from the MPs' perspective, the policy preferences of their constituents are not immediately visible, and even if it were assumed that MPs try to follow their electorate's preferences, it remains unclear how representatives could know what their constituents think.

codes.label: Main research question stated
codes.evidence: The overarching research question addressed in this paper is as follows: Are the policy preferences of less affluent citizens less well represented in the Swiss National Council (lower house of the Federal Assembly) than the preferences of richer citizens?

codes.label: Sub-question on alternative explanations
codes.evidence: A three-step strategy addresses this issue. First, the differences in policy preferences of various income groups are studied. Second, the policy preferences of citizens are linked to representatives' policy preferences, which explores whether the latter support policies that are closer to the preferences of particular income groups. Third, two alternative explanations for unequal representation of citizens with varying incomes are tested: the impact of political participation and that of political information.

codes.label: None

codes.label: Quantitative (descriptive, bivariate, statistical aggregation)
codes.evidence: To assess whether there are significant differences in terms of policy preferences across these income groups, an analysis of variance is performed. This simple statistical model allows testing on whether there are significant differences in means across groups... Table 1 provides the level of significance of differences across groups and a measure of effect size (eta square)... The Kruksal-Wallis, respectively Mann Whitney U, tests indicate that the differences in the median between income groups as well as between all citizens and MPs are significant

codes.label: Quantitative (statistical modelling, regression analysis)
codes.evidence: In order to disentangle these differences, an analysis of subgroups of the income categories is performed. The idea is to test whether the observed bias in the representation of policy preferences of income groups persists even if we focus only on those citizens who have a high level of political knowledge and those who participate in politics.

codes.label: Income-based policy preference differences
codes.evidence: eight out of the 13 issues are significantly related with household income... Unsurprisingly, household income is most strongly associated with policy positions on issues that are related to the economy... The two statements that most clearly divide citizens on an income basis are directly related to redistribution on the one hand and social security on the other. In both cases, citizens with lower incomes are more supportive of these policies

codes.label: Under-representation of poor citizens
codes.evidence: the median representative holds a position that is closer to the preferences of richer citizens than to poorer ones... the proximity of citizens' policy preferences to the positions of representatives increases with income.

codes.label: Persistence of bias beyond participation and information
codes.evidence: even the subgroups of poor citizens who have high political knowledge or participate in politics are farther away from the median position of the parliament than citizens of the upper third of the income distribution... the identified representation gap can only to a limited extent be explained by diverging levels of political participation and political knowledge across income groups

codes.label: Study characteristics
codes.evidence: Empirical study using primary survey data from Swiss Electoral Study 2007. Compares policy preferences across three income tertiles using descriptive statistics and comparative analysis. Focus is on substantive representation measured through policy congruence between citizens and MPs on economic and social policy issues. Sample includes 2291 citizens and 124 elected MPs (out of 200).
